articles.headline: Circuit City to Shut Down
articles.snippet: The troubled consumer electronics chain is the latest retailer to go out of business.
articles.abstract: The troubled consumer electronics chain is the latest retailer to go out of business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Circuit City Stores, a bellwether American retailer, said Friday that it would go out of business, stripping the nation of its second-largest consumer electronics chain.

articles.headline: Preparing Your Budget for Disaster
articles.snippet: What would happen to your finances if you lost your job tomorrow?
articles.abstract: What would happen to your finances if you lost your job tomorrow?
articles.lead_paragraph: Those of us prone to financial daydreaming spend a lot of time on the lotto fantasy. We create elaborate Excel spreadsheets in our head sorting what we would buy, whom we would help and when we’d retire.

articles.headline: In Search of One Bold Stroke to Save the Banks
articles.snippet: Any systemic solution to the government’s endless bank bailouts has to deal with the bad assets, once and for all.
articles.abstract: Any systemic solution to the government’s endless bank bailouts has to deal with the bad assets, once and for all.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the immortal words of Yogi Berra, it’s déjà vu all over again.

articles.headline: Outsourced Chores Come Back Home
articles.snippet: Businesses like salons and dog walkers are feeling the pinch as the economy makes more Americans self-reliant.
articles.abstract: Businesses like salons and dog walkers are feeling the pinch as the economy makes more Americans self-reliant.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few months ago, as her family’s income fell, Laura French Spada, a real estate agent in Glen Rock, N.J., began dyeing her hair at home and washing the family cars herself. Her husband, Mark, started learning how to do electrical repairs.

articles.headline: Weighing Crimes and Ethics in the Fog of Urban Warfare
articles.snippet: Whatever the results of the war in Gaza, Israel is again facing serious accusations over the legality of its military conduct.
articles.abstract: Whatever the results of the war in Gaza, Israel is again facing serious accusations over the legality of its military conduct.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Your unit, on the edges of the northern Gaza town of Jabaliya, has taken mortar fire from the crowded refugee camp nearby. You prepare to return fire, and perhaps you notice — or perhaps you don’t, even though it’s on your map — that there is a United Nations school just there, full of displaced Gazans. You know that international law allows you to protect your soldiers and return fire, but also demands that you ensure that there is no excessive harm to civilians. Do you remember all that in the chaos?

articles.headline: ’92 Ponzi Case Missed Signals About Madoff
articles.snippet: In a case linked to Bernard L. Madoff in 1992, federal investigators took some explanations at face value.
articles.abstract: In a case linked to Bernard L. Madoff in 1992, federal investigators took some explanations at face value.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seventeen years ago, federal investigators questioned for the first time whether Bernard L. Madoff was connected to a Ponzi scheme. Their inquiry centered on Frank Avellino, an accountant who had been funneling investors to Mr. Madoff since the 1960s.

articles.headline: Boxee, Used to View Web on TV, Generates Buzz
articles.snippet: Some of Boxee’s fans say the free software allows them to give up their costly cable or satellite TV connection.
articles.abstract: Some of Boxee’s fans say the free software allows them to give up their costly cable or satellite TV connection.
articles.lead_paragraph: Piping Internet video into a television seems as if it should be simple  after all, a screen is a screen. But consumer electronics and media companies have been moving toward that combination with painstaking caution, both because of technical limitations and to protect their existing business models.

articles.headline: The Popular Newsweekly Becomes a Lonely Category
articles.snippet: The business of telling people what happened in the last week is just about gone, in favor of telling them how to think about the news.
articles.abstract: The business of telling people what happened in the last week is just about gone, in favor of telling them how to think about the news.
articles.lead_paragraph: And then there was one.

articles.headline: Israel Declares Cease-Fire; Hamas Says It Will Fight On
articles.snippet: Israel said its troops would remain in Gaza for now, but Hamas has made a pullout of the area a condition for a cease-fire on their part.
articles.abstract: Israel said its troops would remain in Gaza for now, but Hamas has made a pullout of the area a condition for a cease-fire on their part.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel declared late Saturday that a unilateral cease-fire would begin in Gaza within hours, but said its troops would remain in place for now.

articles.headline: Bailout Is a Windfall to Banks, if Not to Borrowers
articles.snippet: Most banks that received bailout money are using it to pay down debt or to make investments, not lending.
articles.abstract: Most banks that received bailout money are using it to pay down debt or to make investments, not lending.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the Palm Beach Ritz-Carlton last November, John C. Hope III, the chairman of Whitney National Bank in New Orleans, stood before a ballroom full of Wall Street analysts and explained how his bank intended to use its $300 million in federal bailout money.

articles.headline: Poll Finds Faith in Obama, Mixed With Patience
articles.snippet: Americans are confident Barack Obama can turn the economy around but are prepared to give him years to do so, according to the latest Times/CBS News poll.
articles.abstract: Americans are confident Barack Obama can turn the economy around but are prepared to give him years to do so, according to the latest Times/CBS News poll.
articles.lead_paragraph: President-elect Barack Obama is riding a powerful wave of optimism into the White House, with Americans confident he can turn the economy around but prepared to give him years to deal with the crush of problems he faces starting Tuesday, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Marjorie Connelly

articles.headline: 2 Years After Campaign Began, a Different World
articles.snippet: The agenda Barack Obama is setting out to enact is significantly altered from what he had in mind when he began his candidacy.
articles.abstract: The agenda Barack Obama is setting out to enact is significantly altered from what he had in mind when he began his candidacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The world looked very different on the frigid Saturday in February 2007 when Barack Obama stood in front of the Old State Capitol in Springfield, Ill., and declared himself a candidate for president of the United States.

articles.headline: Hedge Funds, Unhinged
articles.snippet: Two out of three hedge funds lost money last year. How many will claw their way back to profitability?
articles.abstract: Two out of three hedge funds lost money last year. How many will claw their way back to profitability?
articles.lead_paragraph: Chicago

articles.headline: The End of Banking as We Know It
articles.snippet: The crisis is an opportunity to go back to a banking model designed to do more than simply enrich folks at the top.
articles.abstract: The crisis is an opportunity to go back to a banking model designed to do more than simply enrich folks at the top.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE concept of the financial supermarket  the all-things-to-all-people, intergalactic, behemoth banking institution  bit the dust last week.

articles.headline: Can CNN, the Go-to Site, Get You to Stay?
articles.snippet: CNN.com ranks first in news and the site is trying to extend that reach through more experimental forays.
articles.abstract: CNN.com ranks first in news and the site is trying to extend that reach through more experimental forays.
articles.lead_paragraph: K. C. ESTENSON, the new general manager of CNN.com, has a thought or two about most news sites on the Web: they’re predictable and homogeneous. Seen one, seen ’em all.

articles.headline: British Banks, After Bailout, in Line for More
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Gordon Brown plans to unveil a second bailout for British banks to stoke more lending.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Gordon Brown plans to unveil a second bailout for British banks to stoke more lending.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  To stabilize a teetering economy, the government bails out several of the nation’s largest banks in hopes that credit will flow again. When that does not work, officials return with yet more taxpayer money and, this time, new initiatives to goad banks into lending.

articles.headline: Inauguration Crowd Will Test Cellphone Networks
articles.snippet: The cellphone industry has a plea for the throngs descending on the nation’s capital for the presidential inauguration: go easy on the mobile communications.
articles.abstract: The cellphone industry has a plea for the throngs descending on the nation’s capital for the presidential inauguration: go easy on the mobile communications.
articles.lead_paragraph: The cellphone industry has a plea for the throngs descending on the nation’s capital for the presidential inauguration: go easy on the mobile communications.

articles.headline: Fox News Primes Itself for a Shift
articles.snippet: Far from being subdued by the shift in the country’s mood, the cable news network of choice during the George W. Bush years seems re-energized.
articles.abstract: Far from being subdued by the shift in the country’s mood, the cable news network of choice during the George W. Bush years seems re-energized.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When the White House changes occupants this week, it may also change channels.

articles.headline: Can Sundance Get a Break?
articles.snippet: While creator Robert Redford is criticized that the film festival is far too commercial, the knock on Sundance this year has been that it will not be commercial enough.
articles.abstract: While creator Robert Redford is criticized that the film festival is far too commercial, the knock on Sundance this year has been that it will not be commercial enough.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah

articles.headline: Cost of Borrowing Zooms Up for Corporations
articles.snippet: Companies with shaky credit are especially vulnerable as their debts come due, and are likely to be among the earliest of many expected defaults this year.
articles.abstract: Companies with shaky credit are especially vulnerable as their debts come due, and are likely to be among the earliest of many expected defaults this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like consumers and homeowners, America’s corporations binged on easy credit when times were flush, racking up huge debts. Now the bills are due, and paying them back will not be easy, or cheap.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Billionaire Seeks Deal in Times Co.
articles.snippet: Carlos Slim Helú is near a deal to invest about $250 million in The New York Times Company, according to people briefed on the transaction.
articles.abstract: Carlos Slim Helú is near a deal to invest about $250 million in The New York Times Company, according to people briefed on the transaction.
articles.lead_paragraph: Carlos Slim Helú, the Mexican billionaire, is near a deal to invest about $250 million in The New York Times Company, helping to shore up the publishing company’s struggling finances, according to people briefed on the transaction.

articles.headline: Parsing Gains of Gaza War
articles.snippet: Have three weeks of overpowering war by Israel weakened Hamas as Israel had hoped, or simply caused acute human suffering?
articles.abstract: Have three weeks of overpowering war by Israel weakened Hamas as Israel had hoped, or simply caused acute human suffering?
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA  The Parliament building here has been reduced to rubble. The five-story engineering department of the Islamic University is a pile of folded concrete. Police stations, mosques and hundreds of homes have been blown away.

articles.headline: 2 Churches, Black and White, See Inaugural Hope
articles.snippet: A black congregation and a white congregation, separate since 1829, will come together for the inauguration.
articles.abstract: A black congregation and a white congregation, separate since 1829, will come together for the inauguration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two Methodist churches have stood on the same block on Capitol Hill for a century, one congregation black and the other white, and in between lies the sorry detritus of a nation’s racial history.

articles.headline: More Americans Joining Military as Jobs Dwindle
articles.snippet: The last fiscal year was a banner one for the military, with forces meeting or exceeding their recruitment goals for the first time since 2004.
articles.abstract: The last fiscal year was a banner one for the military, with forces meeting or exceeding their recruitment goals for the first time since 2004.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the number of jobs across the nation dwindles, more Americans are joining the military, lured by a steady paycheck, benefits and training.
